Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Story: I was on a video call with my team, screen sharing the code for a UI bug that QA flagged again this morning. My manager’s voice was in my ear, reminding me that even minor glitches could erode user trust. I was halfway through explaining my plan for a fix when I glanced out the window and saw my younger brother, phone in hand, stepping off the curb without looking. My heart jumped. I knew I should shout, run outside, do something—anything—to keep him safe. But my team was waiting, watching my cursor hover over the problematic line of code. If I left now, I’d disrupt the meeting and delay the fix, letting down my colleagues and risking another round of complaints. If I stayed, I’d be ignoring the instinct to protect my brother, the expectation that I’d always look out for him. My mind raced, torn between the urgent pull of family and the professional responsibility pressing in from my screen.
